newsitem.title: USA: Adobe Systems first-quarter profit rises 35 percent.
newsitem.headline: Adobe Systems first-quarter profit rises 35 percent.

text.p: Adobe Systems Inc. said Tuesday that profits jumped 35 percent in its first quarter, much better than Wall Street expected, on strong sales of its graphics editing software.

The company, based in San Jose, Calif., also said it plans to pay a dividend based on the money it has made from investing in other public companies. Adobe runs a venture capital operation that has invested in many Silicon Valley companies including Netscape Communications Corp.

For the quarter ended Feb. 28, Adobe's profit from operations rose to $45.4 million, or 61 cents a share, from $33.7 million, or 44 cents a share. With a one-time gain, the company had net income of $46.5 million, or 63 cents a share, in the latest quarter.
Analysts expected Adobe, the third-biggest personal computer software company, to earn 51 cents a share, according to Zacks Investment Research, which tracks estimates.
Revenue rose 17 percent to $226.5 million from $193.6 million.

Adobe writes computer programmes that help graphic artists design publications and produce illustrations. Revenue from applications, aided by the recent release of a new version of its flagship PageMaker product, rose to $175 million in the quarter from $146.7 million a year ago.
Adobe also runs an operation that invests in technology startups. Some of those startups, including Netscape, have gone public, which has sent $72.6 million in cash to Adobe's coffers.

Adobe said it will distribute some of that profit it its investors from time to time in a special dividend, pending board approval. The first dividend could be paid within a few months, the company said.
